CONVEYANCE OF GRIFFITH PROJECT. The Griffith Project Prepayment and Conveyance Act transfers all liability and ownership of the Griffith Project from the United States to the Authority upon prepayment of $121,204,348. This includes improvements, facilities, acquired lands, and reserved interests as of the date of the Act. The Act transfers ownership of the Griffith Project to the Authority upon prepayment. It includes acquired lands, reserved interests, and a right-of-way across Public and Federal lands for project operation. The Act transfers ownership of the Griffith Project to the Authority upon prepayment, including rights-of-way for municipal water supply purposes. Within twelve months, the Secretary and the Authority must agree on the land description and memorialize the rights-of-way. If the conveyance does not occur within twelve months, a report must be submitted to Congress. The Act allows for modification of existing contracts and permits to align with its provisions. It also addresses the relationship between the Act and other laws, as well as future benefits. The Authority must comply with laws and regulations if changing the use of the Griffith Project. Upon conveyance, the Griffith Project will no longer receive Reclamation benefits and will no longer be a Federal Reclamation Project. Federal ownership and rights in Lake Mead National Recreation Area associated lands will not be affected. The Act does not affect the National Park Service's authority over Lake Mead National Recreation Area or Federal reclamation law regarding water delivery to the Authority. Upon conveyance of the Griffith Project, the United States will not be liable for any damages related to its prior ownership.
